title: Lale Orta
text:
Lale Orta (born 1960) is a <a href="Turkish%20women%20in%20sports">Turkish</a> former <a href="association%20football">football</a> player, coach, <a href="sports%20commentator">sports commentator</a> and <a href="Referee%20%28association%20football%29">referee</a>. She was Turkey's first ever <a href="FIFA%20International%20Referees%20List">FIFA listed woman referee</a>. Currently, <a href="Turkish%20women%20in%20academics">she is an academic</a> in the field of sports science.
Personal life.
Lale Orta was born 1960 in <a href="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>. Following her primary and secondary education in schools at <a href="Aksaray%2C%20Istanbul">Aksaray</a>, Cibali and <a href="Bak%C4%B1rk%C3%B6y">Bakırköy</a>, she studied Accounting and Finance at <a href="Marmara%20University">Marmara University</a> graduating in 1986. She continued her higher education in <a href="Sport%20management">Sport management</a> at the same university and earned a <a href="Master%27s%20degree">Master's degree</a> in 1993. She received a <a href="Doctor%20of%20Philosophy">Ph.D.</a> degree with a <a href="thesis">thesis</a> on "Football Organizations in Turkey and the World - An Analytical Approach" () at her <a href="alma%20mater">alma mater</a> in 2002.
Between 1998 and 2003, Orta served as lecturer at the <a href="Istanbul%20Technical%20University">Istanbul Technical University</a>. From 2003 to 2009, she taught at <a href="%C3%87anakkale%20Onsekiz%20Mart%20University">Çanakkale Onsekiz Mart University</a>. Since then she has been employed by <a href="Okan%20University">Okan University</a> in Istanbul, first as an assistant professor and as an associate professor starting in 2015, and has acted as the head of the Department of <a href="Sports%20Management">Sports Management</a> between 2009-2011 and 2015 onwards.
Lale Orta is married to film and stage actor Ahmet Orta.
Sports career.
Player and coach.
Between 1976 and 1989, she played football as goalkeeper in <a href="Dostluk%20Spor">Dostluk Spor</a>, the first women's football team of Turkey, and served as its captain. She became later the country's first female certified football coach, and worked as such for Dostluk Spor and the <a href="Turkey%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Turkey women's national football team</a>.
Referee.
Orta began her referee career as an <a href="assistant%20referee%20%28association%20football%29">assistant referee</a> in a match of the Turkish <a href="reserve%20team">reserve team</a> league, called <a href="A2%20Ligi">A2 Ligi</a>, on September 10, 1990. She made her debut as a referee in the same league on October 7, 1990. She was then promoted to officiate in the <a href="TFF%20Third%20League">TFF Third League</a> on October 27, 1990 and in the <a href="TFF%20Second%20League">TFF Second League</a> on January 28, 1996. Orta was appointed to supervise the highest-level Turkish league competitions in the <a href="S%C3%BCper%20Lig">Süper Lig</a> for the first time in the match <a href="Sakaryaspor">Sakaryaspor</a> against <a href="MKE%20Ankarag%C3%BCc%C3%BC">MKE Ankaragücü</a> on May 29, 1999. She served as referee in the <a href="Turkish%20Women%27s%20First%20Football%20League">Turkish Women's First Football League</a> debuting on April 9, 2000. After officiating more than 1,500 amateur and professional football matches including 60 international in various competitions, she retired from active referee career in domestic football after her last match on December 5, 2004. The Turkish Football Federation named her official observer for the Super Lig matches with effect of the 2007–08 season.
In 1995, she received the FIFA badge as one of the first 54 women referees from 27 countries in the world. In this capacity, she officiated international matches in eleven years. Orta was named a "UEFA Elite Referee" among 17 European referees in 2003. On November 28, 2002, Orta supervised the quarter-finals match between <a href="Arsenal%20L.F.C.">Arsenal Ladies</a> and <a href="CSK%20VVS%20Samara%20%28women%27s%20football%20club%29">CSK VVS Samara</a> at the <a href="2002%E2%80%9303%20UEFA%20Women%27s%20Cup">2002–03 UEFA Women's Cup</a> held in <a href="St%20Albans">St Albans</a> England. She oversaw the preliminary round match between <a href="Russia%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Russia</a> and <a href="France%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">France</a> at the <a href="2005%20UEFA%20Women%27s%20Championship%20qualification">2005 UEFA Women's Championship qualification</a> in <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a>, Russia on May 16, 2004 and the final match of <a href="2005%20UEFA%20Women%27s%20Cup%20Final">2005 UEFA Women's Cup</a> between the <a href="Germany">German</a> <a href="1.%20FFC%20Turbine%20Potsdam">1. FFC Turbine Potsdam</a> and the <a href="Sweden">Swedish</a> <a href="Djurg%C3%A5rdens%20IF%20Dam">Djurgårdens IF Dam</a> on May 15, 2005. Due to 45-years of age limit for referees set by the <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a>, Orta's international referee career ended after the <a href="2007%20FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28UEFA%29">2007 FIFA Women's World Cup qualification (UEFA)</a> match she officiated between the national women's teams of <a href="Spain%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Spain</a> and <a href="Belgium%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Belgium</a> played in <a href="Madrid">Madrid</a>, Spain on November 5, 2005. For the <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20UEFA%20Women%27s%20Cup%23Semi-finals">2007–08 UEFA Women's Cup semifinal</a> second-leg match between the Italian <a href="A.S.D.%20C.F.%20Bardolino%20Verona">A.S.D. C.F. Bardolino Verona</a> and the German <a href="1.%20FFC%20Frankfurt">1. FFC Frankfurt</a> teams played in <a href="Verona">Verona</a>, Italy on April 5, 2008, she served as the official observer.
